Posts.Content: sazylazzy wrote: Hi everyone, Well I'm finally eligible for surgery. My lump has shrunk enough and I'm going in tomorrow to have a lumpectomy. When it was first discovered in July07 it was way too big to do anything. I don't know how many lymph's will be removed.  Hopefully only the first chain as my surgeon called it. I say good bye to and good riddance to bad rubbish. Then I can tackle the other areas of cancer. (bones, liver) I'm scared and concerned about recovery on my left arm.  (that's the side of my breast cancer) I'm left handed and hope I will have full usage.  Any words or thoughts about recovery or anything at all about surgery from any of you survivors, I would be most grateful. All of you have been my inspiration from time to time. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Surgery tomorrow! sazylazzy KiminJax

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2008 09:15AM sazylazzy wrote: Bonnie, I've been on femara for 4 months with really good results.  I'm also on a trial for my bones, cause femara will remove your calcium.  The bone treatment is to replace that and help heal the bone cancer.  I have mets on bone, liver and breast. I'm er/pr + Her2- Well bones are healing, liver is responding and breast cancer has decreased by 80%.  It's truely a miracle. No chemo!!! Hang in there!! Hope this helps in your decision.  Cyber hugs to ya.

Posts.Content: sazylazzy wrote: Thought you all might like this in honor of St Pat's day. Oh you don't have to be Irish to understand this one. Enjoy! One night I dreamed I was walking along the beach with the Lord. Many scenes from my life flashed across the sky. In each scene I noticed footprints in the sand. Sometimes there were two sets of footprints, other times there was one only. This bothered me because I noticed that during the low periods of my life when I was suffering from anguish, sorrow, or defeat, I could see only one set of footprints, so I said to the Lord, "You promised me, Lord, that if I followed you, you would walk with me always. But I noticed that during the most trying periods of my life there have only been one set of footprints in the sand. Why, when I have needed you most have you not been there for me?" The Lord replied, "The times when you have seen only one set of footprints, my child, is when I carried you." Mary Stevenson, 1936 Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Footprints sazylazzy sazylazzy

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2007 04:50PM sazylazzy wrote: Amy, Sorry you had to join the club.  I echo Harley's comment that at least you have found it!  I know that doesn't sound just right - right now, but its so true.  Once you have a plan in place and a routine in place you will feel somewhat better. You will feel in charge again. You life has changed forever, already you are a Survivor!  Make sure you have a good team of doctors.  Make sure you have all your questions before your visits.  Make sure your doctors are willing to spend all the time you need with you, even if they have other patients waiting on them. Above all don't go alone.  You WILL not hear everything that's beng said to you.  Someone else will hear things you missed.  My hubby goes sometimes and my daughter goes other times.  Once I had three people on my appt.  A BC survivor, my husband and my daughter.  My doc loved it.  You will need that support trust me. There are many places that you can call locally that you can talk to on the phone or even visit.  We are out here.  You will have your ups and downs.  Your husband will feel helpless.  Your family will feel helpless.  All this is sooo normal. I've been there and sometimes return there.  All very normal.  Don't push yourself.  Spend some good time with family.  Keep informed.  Spend time alone if you need some time alone. But most of all get informed.  You can fight this nasty disease.  Don't spend too much time reading ugly stuff on the internet.  Just keep in mind this is your own journey.  It cannot be replicated by anyone else's journey.  We all are different.  Sorry to ramble, but there are so many great Survivors that so want to support you.  Just let us know and we will be here for you.  Hugs and prays on your trip to fight this ugly thing called cancer!
Posts.Title: Pathology report---NOT Good Amy1971 nancy01

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2008 02:13AM sazylazzy wrote: Hi Bad, First of all, i really like your web site. Very cool. I take O/S Cal which is 50% calcium and 50% Vit D.  Since I'm on femara it naturally takes away my calcium.  If I could say anything I'd say take at least O/S Cal.  We need both calcium and Vit D.

Posts.Content: sazylazzy wrote: My surgery lumpectomy is OVER. Sorry to yell.  I will find out by the end of this week if they got it all.  Suzy how'd your surgery go.  Thank you everyone for the great support.  Hugs to all of you for your kind words.  Now its on to the next place.  I'm hearing that the caner on liver may be able to be burned off.  Its a new technique that it supposed to be less invasive. They go under the skin with a needle an use radiation treatmetn.  We'll see, but that's still down the road when it shrinks a little bit more.  I'll keep ya posted on that one.  LOVE you all.  Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2007 04:06PM sazylazzy wrote: Unfortunately, I feel down sometimes also.  I too have liver mets.  I was dx at a grade 4 from the get go.  No one could see anything on my yearly mammos.  Doc said I could have had it for years and that's why it had time to met.  Anyway last mammo in July looked different then the previous year. After taking a biopsy (which I didn't even know what that was) the test proved cancer. Now I trust my onco doc.  He is wonderful.  I get down and he picks me up.  He said there are many,many, things in his arsenal.  He too, says I will be around for MANY more years.  Medicine has come a long way.  Don't look at the old stats, don't look at any stats.  YOU - ME - and all the rest of us are human beings not STATS. We are individuals.  NOW HOLD YOUR HEAR UP HIGH AND FIGHT THIS "SOB". just my 2 cents again. God bless all of you.
